DataElement.preferredName: Ovary Peritoneum Fallopian Tube Malignant Neoplasm Surgical Procedure Ind-2
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator related to having surgery for malignant neoplasm of one of the paired female reproductive glands containing the ova or germ cells or the tissue that lines the abdominal wall and covers most of the organs in the abdomen or part of the female reproductive tract.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Ovary Peritoneum Fallopian Tube Malignant Neoplasm Surgical Procedure
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to having surgery for malignant neoplasm of one of the paired female reproductive glands containing the ova or germ cells or the tissue that lines the abdominal wall and covers most of the organs in the abdomen or part of the female reproductive tract.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Ovary Peritoneum Fallopian Tube Malignant Neoplasm
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: One of the paired female reproductive glands containing the ova or germ cells; the ovary's stroma is a vascular connective tissue containing numbers of ovarian follicles enclosing the ova; surrounding this stroma is a more condensed layer of stroma called the tunica albuginea.:(PAIR-ih-toe-NEE-um) The tissue that lines the abdominal wall and covers most of the organs in the abdomen.:(fa-LO-pee-in) Part of the female reproductive tract. The long slender tubes through which eggs pass from the ovaries to the uterus.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: One of the paired female reproductive glands containing the ova or germ cells; the ovary's stroma is a vascular connective tissue containing numbers of ovarian follicles enclosing the ova.
The tissue that lines the wall of the abdominal cavity, intestine, mesentery, and pelvic organs. It consists of the parietal peritoneum and the visceral peritoneum.
One of a pair of tubes that extend from the uterus to each of the ovaries. Following ovulation the egg travels down the fallopian tube to the uterus where fertilization may or may not occur.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Property.preferredDefinition: Surgical Procedure is a diagnostic or treatment medical procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue.

Concepts.definition: A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

ReferenceDocuments.name: Does the patient have a curre
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have a current diagnosis of borderline epithelial ovarian tumor or recurrent invasive epithelial ovarian, primary peritoneal or fallopian tube cancer treated with surgery only

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have a current diagnosis of borderline epithelial ovarian tumor or recurrent invasive epithelial ovarian cancer treated with surgery only?

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text 1
ReferenceDocuments.description: Newly diagnosed stage III or IV epithelial ovarian, fallopian or primary peritoneal carcinoma with ascites and potentially resectable disease agreeing to debulking surgery as standard therapy

ReferenceDocuments.name: NRG_CRF Text
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have a history of recurrent invasive epithelial ovarian, primary peritoneal or fallopian tube cancer treated with surgery only (e.g. Stage 1A or IB low-grade epithelial ovarian or fallopian tube cancers)?

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text 2
ReferenceDocuments.description: Newly diagnosed stage III or IV epithelial ovarian, fallopian or primary peritoneal carcinoma with or without ascites and potentially resectable disease agreeing to debulking surgery as standard therapy.
